title: 108_hr2601
content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act highlights key points. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the United States Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and useful arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times. This serves to provide economic incentives for creators and promotes society's interest in the free flow of ideas and information. The copyright term is limited to ensure the public is not permanently deprived of the benefits of an artist's work. Both commercial and noncommercial creators rely on copyright protection. Both commercial and noncommercial creators benefit from a healthy public domain. Book publishers print public domain titles at reduced prices, while others use it as raw material for new productions. Schools, museums, and libraries utilize public domain works for educational and cultural purposes. Media sources like the World Wide Web also benefit from public domain content. Current law grants copyright protection to works published as early as 1923, but the majority of older works are no longer commercially available. The existing copyright system prevents abandoned works from entering the public domain for many years, hindering the ability of entities to build upon and preserve them. This goes against the original intent of the Framers of the Constitution and Congress in enacting the Copyright Act. It is necessary to establish a mechanism to address abandoned American copyrights. Establish a mechanism for abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE FEE FOR PUBLISHED UNITED STATES WORKS. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17 is amended for works created on or after January 1, 1978, and section 303(a) is amended for works created but not published or copyrighted before January 1, 1978. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended regarding subsisting copyrights, subject to section 306. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include maintenance fees for published United States works under section 306. The Register of Copyrights will charge a $1 fee for maintaining the copyright, due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter until the end of the copyright term. The copyright will expire if the fee is not paid within 6 months of the due date. Ancillary and promotional works related to the copyrighted work are also covered. The maintenance fee must be accompanied by a prescribed form and may satisfy registration provisions. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 3 of title 17, United States Code. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures to ease the submission of maintenance fee forms and make the information easily accessible to the public within 12 months of this Act's enactment.
